Award.AwardTitle: Water, Salt, and Temperature Effects in Polyelectrolyte Complexes and Multilayers
Award.AbstractNarration:
PART 1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This research concerns ultra-thin films of polymers containing electrical charges, which are known as "polyelectrolytes". They can be formed in multilayers and molecular complexes and are of interest in applications ranging from biomedical to temperature-responsive materials. Such polyelectrolytes undergo an unusual "glass-melt" or softening transition whose nature and time-dependence are not well understood. Here the PI proposes to evaluate the direct origin of this transition using experimental techniques that will probe it on a molecular level. This will provide a firm view of how the transition and its dynamics interrelate with regard to temperature, water, and charges arising from different salts. This project places a unique emphasis on salt type, where a broad range of salts with varying size, charge, and water interactions are examined. One possible outcome is a unified relationship among temperature, water, and salt as it governs the transition. This will be of significant importance because this new knowledge will allow fine-tuning of the transition temperature and the physical properties associated with these materials, ultimately leading to possible new advanced applications. A major element of the proposed research is to educate, mentor, and train a future generation of diverse workers skilled in science as well as to offer science outreach to the general public both locally and online.


PART 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Experiments are proposed to investigate the nature of the thermal transition observed in hydrated polyelectrolyte complexes and multilayers. If successful, this project will shed new light on water's role in the thermal transition. Possible outcomes include the experimental verification of the role of polyanion-water interactions in the thermal transition, water and salt relationships with the thermal transition, and evidence of time-temperature-salt-water superpositioning. The proposed approach centers on quartz crystal microbalance with dissipation, differential scanning calorimetry, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, temperature-controlled Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and dynamic mechanical analysis. The proposed project is comprised of four activities: (1) investigate water-poly(styrene sulfonate) interactions within polyelectrolyte multilayers as a function of temperature, (2) explore and determine the role of water and other solvents, (3) examine and understand the role of salt on the transition, and (4) determine possible water-salt connections and effects on dynamics associated with the transition. Educational components of the proposed work include training and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as outreach locally and through the NAE EngineerGirl website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the presence of water, many materials deform as the materials softens. This goal of this project was to understand how water affected the softening point (or the glass transition temperature) of a specific class of materials called polyelectrolyte complexes and multilayers. These materials are formed by the association of oppositely charged polymers to form a larger structure called a ?complex? or a ?multilayer?, depending on whether the polymers are mixed abruptly or in a layer-by-layer fashion. The association sites for these oppositely charged polymers act as crosslinks and dictate many observable physical properties such as stiffness, strength, and glass transition temperature. This project centered upon how water molecules interacted with these association sites and whether this interaction would affect bulk-scale physical properties. Experimental methods such as calorimetry, spectroscopy, mechanical testing, and quartz crystal microbalance were employed. The association sites were found to be particularly sensitive to the water content, the amount of salt (sodium chloride, for example) present, and the temperature. As a result, this work uncovered a general equation that connected water content and number of association sites to the glass transition temperature in polyelectrolyte complexes and multilayers. So far, this equation has been successful in capturing the behavior of several different polyelectrolyte systems exposed to different salts (sodium chloride, potassium bromide). The influence of these salts on multilayer structure and swelling in water was also investigated, showing that swelling is balanced by electrostatic repulsion at low salt concentrations and film disintegration at high salt concentrations.

Together, this work impacts sectors involving synthetic polymers, natural polymers, and proteins. Potential applications impacted include reconfigurable materials, functional coatings and biology (membraneless organelles).

Outreach was conducted by the PI and graduate student participants via TAMU?s Chemistry Open House, Discovery Night at local elementary schools, and curricular development.

This work was complemented by collaborations with individuals at Pennsylvania State University, Aalto University in Finland, and Jerzy Haber Institute of Catalysis and Surface Chemistry Polish Academy of Sciences.

This project produced eight peer-reviewed publications, three doctoral theses, and one masters students. Five graduate students and nine undergraduates were mentored. Of the 15 project participants (including the PI), nine were female and two were under-represented minorities.

Modified by: Jodie Lutkenhaus

Image
  • Schematic of a charged polyelectrolyte assembly. The charged polyelectrolyte assembly contains two different types of ion pairs: intrinsic and extrinsic. Intrinsic ion pairs are polycation-polyanion pairs (association sites), and extrinsic ion pairs are polyelectrolyte-counterion pairs.
    Produced by Lutkenhaus. Reproduced from ACS Cent. Sci. 2018, 4, 5, 638?644
    Creative Commons
    Jodie Lutkenhaus
    Schematic of a charged polyelectrolyte assembly.
